content.raw:
I don't think that's a great idea - three buttons is a more complicated target than one button, which will be the normal state of affairs - JQI pretty much always has it in repeat-last mode and so would just be hitting that one toggle, use of this menu would be pretty rare. The icon on the button changes to show the mode that is in use (or will be in use once you press the button), so there's not much risk of confusion as to to which mode is set. The tooltip for the dropdown menu button says "select repeat mode". I'm pretty happy with it (and I've pushed it to this pull request, I'd made the changes before your comment), so let me know what you think, and maybe Shaun can weigh in as well.

I think the pause and repeat buttons are good having text since the text is a verb that says what happens when the button is checked. I was reading about this aspect of UI design earlier today, and came across this stack exchange post:

https://ux.stackexchange.com/questions/1318/should-a-toggle-button-show-its-current-state-or-the-state-to-which-it-will-chan

The top answer says this about toggle controls like these:

> The authors (and I think of these as an authority on the subject) presents two possible solutions: You should either spell the button's action out as a verb phrase (e.g., Switch to portrait mode, thereby sacrificing some of the saved space) or use some other technique entirely (e.g., two radio buttons).

We're using verbs - "pause", "repeat", rather than indicating the current state, which seems to be the least confusing option, if you're going to use toggles. Lyse violates this though by saying "analysis running", "analysis paused" with a "play" icon. That's pretty confusing. Maybe the bug report was about that?
